awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Spectrograph for the Central Washington University Research Telescope
awd_abstract_narration:
This Major Research Instrumentation award will fund the acquisition of scientific instrumentation for the new 0.6-meter telescope at Central Washington University (CWU).  The instrument will be a compact, low-cost, high-resolution spectrograph designed to detect and measure the orbital characteristics of Jupiter-sized planets around nearby giant stars.  While the design is based on an existing instrument, much of the assembly and testing of the instrument will be carried out by undergraduate students. CWU students will also participate in the international partnership that developed the initial design. The spectrograph will give students the opportunity to experience how science, technology, and engineering come together to solve research problems and make new discoveries.

This primary scientific goal is detection and monitoring of exoplanets in long-period orbits around giant stars.  This will be accomplished through long-term monitoring of a small number of bright targets, which should also enable asteroseismology of giant stars.  The instrument design targets precision radial velocity studies in the m/s range and makes use of an iodine cell. Much of the local engineering work and scientific observations will be performed by undergraduate students.  This will provide training opportunities that generally are not available at non-PhD granting schools.

por.por_cntn:
During Summer 2022, the final assembly of the Echelle spectrograph for the Central Washington University (CWU) 0.6-meter research telescope was completed allowing us to obtain first light through the instrument in July 2022.

During the initial years of the project (years 1-2), optical design of the system along with mechanical design of the optics mounts were prioritized. Initial site preparation and testing on location at CWU was completed.

The middle years (years 3-4) included efforts to prepare and adapt the CWU 0.6-meter telescope for integration with the spectrograph. Significant modification of the telescope backend took place to accommodate the addition of the instrument at the focal plane. Additionally, preparation of the fiber routing system and instrument housing took place. Some of the instrument?s optical components were acquired and some of the mechanical mounts were manufactured.

In the final years (years 5-6) of the award, the remaining mechanical mounts were manufactured and all remaining optical components were sourced or made. Peripheral systems including fiber preparation and spectrograph enclosure were finalized. Final assembly and alignment of the instrument took place and first light was achieved near the end of the award period. Commissioning is ongoing.

As CWU is primarily an undergraduate institution, the spectrograph has already significantly contributed to the research activities for faculty and students in the physics, astronomy, and science education programs at CWU and will continue to enhance future research activities for these groups. Additionally, CWU has a strong commitment to public engagement, and multiple presentations relating to the spectrograph were made to broad audiences in the communities surrounding CWU.

Over the six-year lifespan of the award, six CWU undergraduate students (including three who identify as a member of an underrepresented population in physics) and two Macquarie University PhD students were involved in the project. The project gave these students the opportunity to participate in the joining of science, technology and engineering to build an instrument that will allow us to conduct spectroscopic research. One of the CWU undergraduate students involved went on to graduate school and two others plan to do so upon their graduation.

Short-term projects during the commissioning phase will allow students in the CWU Observational Astronomy and Undergraduate Research classes to measure the spectra of stars, asteroids, and bright supernovae. While we are still at the initial stages of commissioning the instrument, our driving science goal remains the detection of large (Jupiter-size), long-period (Jupiter-length) exoplanets around bright stars and we look forward to the full science operation phase of the spectrograph.
